natural problem: Find all real numbers $x$ between 0 and 360 such that $\sqrt{3} \cos 10^\circ = \cos 40^\circ + \sin x^\circ.$  Enter all the solutions, separated by commas.
natural solution: We have that \begin{align} \sin x^\circ &= \sqrt{3} \cos 10^\circ - \cos 40^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos 30^\circ \cos 10^\circ - \cos (10^\circ + 30^\circ). \end{align}From the angle addition formula, \begin{align}

\end{align}From the angle subtraction formula, \begin{align} \cos 10^\circ \cos 30^\circ + \sin 10^\circ \sin 30^\circ &= \cos (30^\circ - 10^\circ) \\ &= \cos 20^\circ \\ &= \sin 70^\circ. \end{align}The solutions are then $\boxed{70,110}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "x \<le> 360"
and h2 : "sqrt(3) * cos (10 * pi / 180) = cos (40 * pi / 180) + sin (x * pi / 180)"
shows  "x = 70 \<or> x = 110"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all real numbers $x$ between 0 and 360 such that $\sqrt{3} \cos 10^\circ = \cos 40^\circ + \sin x^\circ.$  Enter all the solutions, separated by commas. The final Answer is 70,110
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sin x^\circ &= \sqrt{3} \cos 10^\circ - \cos 40^\circ \\ &= 2 \cos 30^\circ \cos 10^\circ - \cos (10^\circ + 30^\circ). \end{align}From the angle addition formula, \begin{align}
 2 \cos 30^\circ \cos 10^\circ - \cos (10^\circ + 30^\circ) &= 2 \cos 30^\circ \cos 10^\circ - (\cos 10^\circ \cos 30^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \sin 30^\circ) \\ &= \cos 10^\circ \cos 30^\circ + \sin 10^\circ \sin 30^\circ.
 \end{align}From the angle subtraction formula, \begin{align} \cos 10^\circ \cos 30^\circ + \sin 10^\circ \sin 30^\circ &= \cos (30^\circ - 10^\circ) \\ &= \cos 20^\circ \\ &= \sin 70^\circ. \end{align}The solutions are then $\boxed{70,110}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "x \<le> 360"
and h2 : "sqrt(3) * cos (10 * pi / 180) = cos (40 * pi / 180) + sin (x * pi / 180)"
shows  "x = 70 \<or> x = 110"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the values of $x$, between 0 and 360 degrees, for which $\sqrt{3} \cos(10^\circ) = \cos(40^\circ) + \sin(x)$. The final answer is $70^\circ$ or $110^\circ$.
